author: phabc
content: 100% agree. Stateless block production comes with too much complexity that aren't worth waiting for to have stateless nodes imo\.

author: phabc
content: That's an interesting solution, though in practice the only nodes that are incentivized to be stateful will be block producers (they are forced to be) and perhaps indexers / archive nodes (though indexers don't need to be stateful per say). This seems like quite a quite small number of stateful nodes in a PoW world, does it not? This solution seems completely sufficient in a PoS world, but would be nice to have stateless node before the full PoS transition.

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!273808422753796097> did you see my proposal here for adjusting how transaction gossip works?: https://notes.ethereum.org/YtI7e-R5RSK13cklq8j3Ug?view

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm I'm not sure how this solves the stated problem (broadcasting reliably to miners)

author: .vbuterin
content: Can you explain more?

author: pipermerriam
content: There's an "assumption" that a client can attain a "proof" against the sending account.  Based on that assumption, they can then construct the transaction, and broadcast it in the network described in my document along with the proof against a recent state root.  That new gossip network then acts in much the same way as the current gossip network.  Assuming either miners are part of the new gossip network, or there are nodes bridging between the new gossip network and the legacy one (`ETH` on DevP2P), then the transaction will eventually be gossiped to a miner.

author: .vbuterin
content: What do you mean by "a proof against the sending account"

author: .vbuterin
content: A witness that covers just the tx sender account?

author: .vbuterin
content: And that's sufficient to prove to the network that the tx can pay fees?

author: pipermerriam
content: validation of transaction means checking `nonce` and `balance`, so a merkle proof against tx.sender account

author: .vbuterin
content: right, that certainly is clever!

author: pipermerriam
content: (unless we're talking about account abstraction... which makes things complex)

author: .vbuterin
content: Where would these proofs come from?

author: pipermerriam
content: well, if the client is stateful, they can make it themselves.  Infura could provide them.  Or if we're successful in building the <#796057759858425866> network then they could easily be constructed from fetching data from there.

author: .vbuterin
content: right I see

author: .vbuterin
content: Or if the client happens to be directly connected to a stateful peer

author: pipermerriam
content: right, there could be a level of altruism where a peer might signal that they are willing to accept witness-less transactions and that they'll fill in the witness before forwarding.

author: pipermerriam
content: but in general, I like treating them as separate problems.  From the perspective of the gossip network, it doesn't care where the proofs come from.  And from the state network side, it doesn't care why people are looking up state data.

author: .vbuterin
content: got it

author: .vbuterin
content: yeah, the idea that you only need a witness for the tx sender is clever
